10.86.text: To survive in this high pressured, crazy world,

14.14.text: most of us have to become highly adept at self criticism.

18.26.text: We learn how to tell ourselves our froth failures

21.28.text: and for not working hard or smart enough.

23.54.text: But so good are we at this

25.40.text: that we are sometimes in danger of falling pray

28.20.text: to an excessive version of self criticism.

30.90.text: What we might call self flagellation,

33.46.text: a rather dangerous state which just ushes in depression and under performance,

38.00.text: we might simply lose the will to get out of bed.

40.54.text: For those moments, we need a corrective.

43.26.text: We need to carve out time

45.14.text: for an emotional state of which many of us are profoundly suspicious:

51.06.text: We're suspicious because that sounds horribly close to self-pity.

54.92.text: But because depression and self-hatred are serious enemies of a good life,

59.48.text: we need to appreciate the role of self-care

62.82.text: in a good, ambitious and fruitful life.

66.06.text: To this end, we can perform what we've called a self-compassion exercise:

70.94.text: a structured meditation lasting fifteen minutes or so,

74.44.text: lying in bed or perhaps a bath,

76.82.text: turn over your sequence of thoughts that interrupt and correct the flow of your worst self-accusations.

83.78.text: For a time adopt an entirely kindly perspective on your setbacks.

88.18.text: The self-compassion exercise goes like this:

96.88.text: we're so in love with success

98.56.text: we fail to notice the scale of the challenges we routinely set ourselves.

103.40.text: There is nothing remotely normal about what we've tried to achieve.

108.04.text: We failed, but given the mountain we were trying to climb, the conclusion doesn't have to be that we're simply fools.

121.90.text: We have tricky family histories, we all do.

124.78.text: There were things, which happened to us at the hands of others, which can help to explain some of our current troubles.

131.22.text: We are not entirely sane or well, but none of us are.

135.68.text: We weren't well set up to carry out certain tasks,

139.02.text: it isn't wholly our fault in the here and now.

146.30.text: From the media you'd think everyone was rich and famous and successful,

151.18.text: but in reality undramatic, quiet failure is by a huge margin the statistical norm.

158.32.text: We should't tear ourselves apart for not managing to beat what were, in truth, awesome odds.

169.76.text: Tough self-critical people don't allow themselves the indulgence of believing in luck:

177.98.text: they think winners make their own luck, but they don't, for the most part.

182.94.text: Luck is a genuine feature of existence.

185.66.text: We're robbing ourselves a fair consolation by believing that we're entirely in control and, therefore, entirely to blame when we crash.

201.30.text: You are not only your achievements,

203.90.text: status and material success are one bit of you,

207.12.text: but there are others as well.

209.00.text: Those who loved you in childhood knew this and in their best moments helped you to feel it.

214.28.text: Rehearse the internalized voices of all those who have been kind to you,

218.88.text: pave in the memory of a love

231.42.text: It seems it will never end:

233.72.text: that's not the truth, it's just how a crisis feels.

237.68.text: You need to reduce expectations to zero for a time,

241.62.text: take each new hour as it comes, and

244.84.text: without being banal: what you need for most of all is some rest.
